sections.title: The problem: embedded questions
sections.content:
In **direct questions** we use **question word order** (verb before subject):

• **What is the answer?** (verb **is** before subject **the answer**)
• **Where is the station?** (verb **is** before subject **the station**)
• **When did he leave?** (auxiliary **did** before subject **he**)

But when the question is **inside another sentence** (embedded or indirect), English uses **statement word order** (subject before verb):

• I don't know **what the answer is**. (subject **the answer** + verb **is**)
• Can you tell me **where the station is**? (subject **the station** + verb **is**)
• I wonder **when he left**. (subject **he** + verb **left**)

**Wrong (Czech-style):** I don't know what **is the answer**. / I don't know where **is the station**.
**Right (English):** I don't know what **the answer is**. / I don't know where **the station is**.

sections.title: When do we use statement word order?
sections.content:
Use **statement word order** (subject + verb) when the question is embedded after:

• **I don't know** what the answer is. / I don't know where he is.
• **I wonder** when they will arrive. / I wonder why she left.
• **Can you tell me** what time it is? / Can you tell me where the toilet is?
• **Tell me** who that man is. / Tell me how much it costs.
• **Do you know** what his name is? / Do you know if she is coming?
• **I'm not sure** what the problem is. / I'm not sure where we are.
• **It depends on** what you want. / It depends on where we go.

**Rule:** After these expressions, we do **not** invert subject and verb. We use the same order as in a statement: **what the answer is**, not *what is the answer*.

sections.title: Direct question vs embedded question
sections.content:
**Direct question** (standalone) → **question word order** (verb before subject):

• What **is** the answer?
• Where **is** the station?
• When **did** he leave?
• Who **is** that man?
• How much **does** it cost?

**Embedded question** (inside a sentence) → **statement word order** (subject before verb):

• I don't know what the answer **is**.
• Can you tell me where the station **is**?
• I wonder when he **left**.
• Tell me who that man **is**.
• Do you know how much it **costs**?

**Yes/No embedded questions** use **if** or **whether** + statement order:

• I don't know **if she is** coming. (not *if is she coming*)
• I wonder **whether he has** finished. (not *whether has he finished*)

sections.title: Typical Czech learner errors
sections.content:
Czech often uses **inverted (question) word order** in embedded clauses. In English we do not:

• **Wrong:** I don't know what **is the answer**. → **Right:** I don't know what **the answer is**.
• **Wrong:** Can you tell me where **is the station**? → **Right:** Can you tell me where **the station is**?
• **Wrong:** I wonder when **did he leave**. → **Right:** I wonder when **he left**.
• **Wrong:** Do you know what **is his name**? → **Right:** Do you know what **his name is**?
• **Wrong:** I'm not sure what **are the opening hours**. → **Right:** I'm not sure what **the opening hours are**.
• **Wrong:** Tell me how much **does it cost**. → **Right:** Tell me how much **it costs**.

**Tip:** If you can say "I don't know" (or similar) before it, use **statement** word order: subject then verb.

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• **Direct question** (standalone): What **is** the answer? (verb before subject)
• **Embedded question** (inside a sentence): I don't know what **the answer is**. (subject before verb)
• After *I don't know*, *Can you tell me*, *I wonder*, *Tell me*, *Do you know*, *I'm not sure* → use **statement** word order.
• Wrong: I don't know what is the answer. Right: I don't know what the answer is.
